Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: The weekly required religious school class for children is set to occur.
Story: I glance at my phone, rereading the text from my boyfriend: “Let’s do something special this week. We finally have time!” My heart lifts. We’ve both been so busy, and I know how much it means to him—and to me—to have an evening just for us. I start to type a reply, suggesting Thursday, when my calendar notification pops up: “Religious School—Thursday, 6:00 PM.” My stomach tightens. As the rabbi, I’m expected to teach the children’s Torah class every week. The parents count on me, and the kids look forward to our sessions. Canceling or rescheduling isn’t simple; it would disappoint families and disrupt the routine. But if I choose another night for our date, it won’t be the same—Thursday is the only evening he’s truly free. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, the desire to nurture my relationship and the responsibility to my community. My fingers hover over the keyboard, torn between love and duty, wishing I could be in two places at once.
